Clinton remembers Sen. Byrd as her ‘friend,’ ‘mentor’
=====================================================
Today Secretary Clinton, a former U.S. senator representing New York, remarked on the death of her colleague Sen. Robert Byrd (D-W.Va.). She began: Today our country has lost a true American original, my friend and mentor Robert Byrd. Clinton said she remembers most this remark from Byrd, made when they were senators together right after ...
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
By , copy chief at _Foreign Policy_ from 2009-2016 and was an assistant editor from 2007-2009.
!
Mark Wilson/Getty Images
Mark Wilson/Getty Images
June 28, 2010, 4:33 PM
Today Secretary Clinton, a former U.S. senator representing New York, remarked on the  (D-W.Va.).
Today Secretary Clinton, a former U.S. senator representing New York, remarked on the  (D-W.Va.).
:
> Today our country has lost a true American original, my friend and mentor Robert Byrd.
Clinton said she remembers most this remark from Byrd, made when they were senators together right after the 9/11 attacks:
> I will remember him most for a heartfelt comment he made to me in the dark days following 9/11, when my state of New York was reeling and we were scrambling to provide support and relief. "Think of me as the third senator from New York," he said. And he meant it.
Even after Clinton left the Senate and entered the State Department, Byrd continued to provide her advice:
> And...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Foreign Policy is a reputable publication specializing in global politics and international relations. It offers insightful analysis and commentary from experts in the field, but like many editorialized platforms, it may reflect particular biases or viewpoints. Nonetheless, its editorial standards are typically high.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence contains firsthand remarks by Clinton at Byrd’s memorial, where she directly refers to him as a 'friend and mentor,' offering strong confirmation of a personal relationship. It is highly relevant.

Query1.title: Remarks at a Dinner Honoring Senator Robert Byrd | The American ...
Query1.snippet: Jul 17, 1994 ... Thank you very much. Thank you. Senator and Mrs. Byrd, Senator Rockefeller, Congressmen Mollohan, Rahall, and Wise, and Governor Caperton, ...

content.content:
About Search

Thank you very much. Thank you. Senator and Mrs. Byrd, Senator Rockefeller, Congressmen Mollohan, Rahall, and Wise, and Governor Caperton, and friends, I am glad to be here with all you folks from West Virginia, a small State with a lot of mountains. I identify with it.
I'm mostly glad to be here to speak for Senator Byrd tonight. You know, one of the first things I did on coming to Washington as President was to go by Senator Byrd's office and pay a visit. And on that visit, he gave me a copy of his "History of the Senate," which I actually proceeded to read, fearing he would one day give me an examination on it. [Laughter] Now, in this book, among other things, he has a very moving autobiography in which he expresses his respect for Senator Richard Russell and for Senator John Stennis because of the advice and kindness that they gave to him. I feel the same way; I've learned a lot from Senator Byrd. He's always been unfailingly kind, and he's given me a lot of information I've needed and a lot of wise counsel.
Senator Byrd also expresses in this book his friendship for the late President Johnson, and he describes his relationship with President Johnson. And I can identify with that, too. There's a particularly moving part of this autobiography where he describes how he talked L.B.J. into appointing a Federal judge he didn't really want...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: This site is a reliable archival resource that focuses on presidential documents and related materials, providing a comprehensive database of important presidential speeches, papers, and historical documents. It is used by scholars and educators, which adds to its credibility. Its focus on accuracy and historical record earns it a high score, though it may not have extensive real-time fact-checking features.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This source provides a direct quote from Hillary Clinton expressing her gratitude and admiration for Robert Byrd during remarks at a dinner, indicating a friendly and mentor-like relationship. It supports the claim that Byrd was significant in her political career and reflects a personal connection.

Query1.title: Robert C. Byrd Oral History | Miller Center
Query1.snippet: Jun 5, 2006 ... He worked in his committee, and just as I told Mrs. [Hilary Rodham] Clinton once before she became Senator, work your committee. Get to know ...

content.content:
[Content truncated]...’s real. I’m a changed man from what I was and I think Ted is too.
Young
That was going to be my next question, is he too?
Byrd
Yes.
Young
How has he changed? You know, you said he had a lot of tragedy. He had some misfortunes too and his private life was not—
Byrd
Yes, yes. I never thought about that. I never spent my time thinking about such. I had my own private fight that wasn’t so good. I joined the Ku Klux Klan when I was young and didn’t have the right attitude. I came from a background that was part of that, so that is that and I regret it. So I have something in my background that I’ve talked a lot about. I don’t hide from it, but I don’t think about the backgrounds. We came from opposite poles but we’re together.
Young
Let me ask you a question about him. Some people have said about Kennedy that he didn’t really decide to become a Senator, as you put it, in the best sense of the term, until his Presidential ambitions crashed. Some people say that that’s when he became a real Senator and I’ve wondered myself whether that’s true or not. Or was the Senate becoming his life, his place in the world of public service, before that? My question is did this happen after his Presidential ambitions were gone, or did you see it happening after that handshake? 
Byrd
I don’t see it through a glass darkly. I saw it up front. He was a Senator before that time. He worked in his committee, and just as I told Mrs. [Hilary Rodham] Clinton once before she became Senator, work your committee. Get to know the jurisdictions, get to know the work. Get to know what’s in that committee, what’s in the work. He did do just that. He has been a study of mine for a long time. I’m looking from the outside and I’m looking from the inside, and I’ve known him as no other person has known him in a way, and my admiration for his work in committee happened earlier than that. He has mastered the work of his committees and he has mastered the work as a Senator. 
I don’t have to be here today to earn a living. I’ve paid into this retirement system longer than any other person on earth; 48 years I’ve paid into it, and before then when I was in the House. So I don’t have to work here to earn a living...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The Miller Center at the University of Virginia specializes in presidential studies and public policy. It provides well-researched articles, expert analyses, and historical context, making it a strong resource for understanding political figures, including Robert Byrd. The academic rigor and emphasis on historical accuracy support its high rating.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This oral history features Byrd giving advice to Hillary Clinton before she became a senator and shows that there was a level of communication and mentorship. It implies that Byrd played a role in her political journey, thus supporting the claim of a relationship.

Query2.title: Hillary Clinton Remembers 'Friend and Mentor' Robert Byrd | Observer
Query2.snippet: Jun 28, 2010 ... 'Think of me as the third senator from New York,' he said. And he meant it. Thanks to the leadership of Senator Byrd, who chaired the ...

content.content:
[Content truncated]... he had a personal friendship–the late West Virginia Senator Robert Byrd  in the Democratic primary, just four days after his state had voted overwhelmingly for Clinton.
As Sam Stein notes, it was a  for both Byrd and Obama, whose team did its best to publicize the symbolism of a former KKK member throwing his support to the man who would become the first black president.
Clinton had become friends with Byrd during her time in the Senate, and had even lunched with Byrd and Clinton’s mother, who came to admire him while monitoring C-SPAN for her daughter’s floor appearances.
This morning, Secretary of State Hillary Clinton put out her own statement eulogizing Byrd as a “friend and mentor” as “a man of unsurpassing eloquence and nobility.”
“It is almost impossible to imagine the United States Senate without Robert Byrd. He was not just its longest serving member, he was its heart and soul. From my first day in the Senate, I sought out his guidance, and he was always generous with his time and his wisdom,” Clinton wrote.
“I will remember him most for a heartfelt comment he made to me in the dark days following 9/11, when my state of New York was reeling and we were scrambling to provide support and relief. ‘Think of me as the third senator from New York,’ he said. And he meant it. Thanks to the leadership of Senator Byrd, who chaired the Appropriations Committee, New Yorkers got the help they needed. I will never forget his devotion and his friendship in that critical time.”
Here’s her full statement:
> Today our country has lost a true American original, my friend and mentor Robert Byrd.
> 
> Senator Byrd was a man of surpassing eloquence and nobility. I will remember him most for a heartfelt comment he made to me in the dark days following 9/11, when my state of New York was reeling and we were scrambling to provide support and relief. “Think of me as the third senator from New York,” he said. And he meant it. Thanks to the leadership of Senator Byrd, who chaired the Appropriations Committee, New Yorkers got the help they needed. I will never forget his devotion and his friendship in that critical time.
> 
> It is almost impossible to imagine the United States Senate without Robert Byrd. He was not just its longest serving member, he was its heart and soul. From my first day in the Senate, I sought out his guidance, and he was...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Observer is an online news publication that covers politics, business, arts, and technology. While it has editorial standards and provides investigative journalism, it has faced criticism for sensationalism in some of its reporting.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This article elaborates on their relationship, quoting Clinton's own words about Byrd and describing her respectful views toward him. It emphasizes their friendship and professional mentorship, directly supporting the claim of a personal relationship.

QA.Question: Does the video evidence support the claim of a personal relationship between Hillary Clinton and Robert Byrd?
QA.Answer: The video evidence supports the claim of a personal relationship between Hillary Clinton and Robert Byrd. In her remarks, Clinton refers to Byrd as her "friend" and "mentor," indicating a deep personal connection. She recalls the heartfelt support he provided during the trying times after the 9/11 attacks, stating that he offered to "think of me as the third senator from New York," which further emphasizes the bond they shared while serving in the Senate together. Moreover, Clinton's acknowledgment of Byrd's impact on her work and his continued support even after she left the Senate underscores their relationship beyond just colleagues. She mentions her reliance on his advice and counsel throughout her career, which signifies a mentor-mentee dynamic as well as a personal friendship. Collectively, this evidence suggests that the nature of their relationship was both professional and personal, marked by mutual respect and support. Therefore, we can confidently conclude that the video evidence does support the claim of a personal relationship between Hillary Clinton and Robert Byrd.
